div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Observer, September 29, 1900
div1.p:
People Who Have Answered the Last
Roll Call.

An official telegram from Cuba conveys
the sad intelligence of the death of Dr.
Jesse W. Lazear, a young physician of
great promise in whom the citizens of
Washington and Western Pennsylvania
feel an unusual interest. Dr. Lazear to-
gether with his mother and younger
brother was as a boy for some years a
resident of this place, attending Trinity
Hall and Washington and Jefferson col-
lege, which institution he left some time
in the latter eighties. removing with his
mother to Baltimore. where he entered
the Johns Hopkins University, graduating
from the medical department with high
honors. A year spent abroad still
further fitted him for the practice of his
noble profession. Last spring by ap-
pointment of the United States govern-
ment he, in company with two other
physicians, went to Cuba to make a criti-
cal study of that dread scourge of the
tropics, yellow fever, to which he has
fallen a victim. Some years since he
was united in marriage to Miss Mabel
Houstman, a native of the state of Cali-
fornia, who survives him together with
two children. His family had accom-
panied him on his visit to Cuba. Dr. La-
zear comes of an old and honored Penn-
sylvania family, his grandfather being
the Hon. Jesse Lazear, of Uniontown.
His father was William Lazear. T. C.
Lazear, Esq., of Pittsburg, is an uncle.
His untimely death is a loss to the pro-
fession of medicine, to which he was most
devoted. He as truly died for mankind
and his country as if he had fallen in the
din of battle while following the flag.
His wife and children have the sympa-
thy of an appreciative country.
